This needs to happen. It would be especially helpful for those building communities and that are capable of running their own dedicated servers. Having to leave a device logged into a world 24/7 just so others can join is not practical, because it pauses the world and does not allow others to join if the host has the game paused or running in the background. Playing your own world offers 8 player slots, and a realm only offers 10, so paying for a realm is not plausible at the extra cost. Especially when a dedicated server on a really good internet connection could easily handle 20+ players at one time.

PC users have a button in the Servers tab to "Add Server", and it should be present on all devices/consoles. This suggestion is three years old at this point and is becoming more and more relevant for many players in this era, but not enough people know to come here to make suggestions like this.

Developers can use the same concept for this as is available to PC users at no additional impact other than making it noted to users on certain devices if their device is not compatible with the add-ons included on that dedicated server.

Developers of Mojang:

I have been playing Minecraft since 2014 and I now work on Bukkit plugins. Currently, I'm working on a punishment plugin (github/A248). For developers, there are 2 main sources of UUID/name conversion information. First, minecraft servers maintain their own internal cache of players who've joined the server. Second, Mojang maintains its API which servers use to lookup the UUIDs of new players.

Using the internal cache only, it is impossible to use the names of players who have not joined a server in a plugin which runs on that server. For example, "/ban player1" will not work if "player1" has never joined the server. This is not ideal. Consequently, plugin developers often incorporate the Mojang API into their plugins. Using the Mojang API lets plugins accept playername inputs of players who have not joined the server.

However, the Mojang API's limits, while well-intentioned, make these kinds of operations hard. as such, my plugin will check the internal cache, check its own cache, check a third-party API, and then finally check the Mojang API. It is, for sure, not an ideal solution, but it's better than prohibiting banning players who have never joined before.

CONTINUED

CONTINUED

The official rate limit is so harsh that github/Electroid has created a third-party API which isn't rate limited in any way. His API is essentially a massive cache of Mojang API results + the ability to bundle queries into a single request. There have been other similar third-party API services. These sites function as another layer of caching and resolution.

It strikes me as terribly inefficient that there are several levels of caching which developers require for a simple name/UUID conversion. In fact, I have heard of large servers utilising multiple IP addresses in order to bypass rate limiting; I do not agree with such actions, but I would prefer they were not necessary for those large servers which undertake them. Please consider reducing the official rate limits. The Mojang API is the only one which developers can rely on for consistently reliable resolution.

Thanks,

A248
